messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...
messages.msgSnippet: Hey Ron,                     Once again, I thank you for your advice. It s always great to hear from you.   Mark   ... From:
messages.messageBody:
Hey Ron,
                    Once again, I thank you for your advice. It's always
great to hear from you.
 
Mark
 

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Monday, January 09, 2006 3:13 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...


Hi Mark -

As Patrik wrote a few messages ago, he has purhased the sword and at the
price, I would think he could not had gone wrong with it. Will be quite
interesting to see if the blade has a mei or not! (Trying to get an atari
with my Bungo-to thought!)

>Has anyone else out there been denied access to a nakago? I'm curious.

In the past fast-approaching 40 years (now that sound scarey!!) I would
suspect I've been denied access to a nakago perhaps half-dozen times. If you
have the opportunity to have the sword in-hand, then at least you can make a
judgement from the blade's quality. If buying it from a photo, well, it is a
gamble and would certainly limit how much you would offer for it because of
that gamble. I've found that most "owners" will, if you explain it to them
in a knowledgeable and polite manner, will allow the tsuka to be removed. If
buying through the mail, once they learn about the possibility of a
signature, curiosity usually takes over and off comes the tsuka. (Always
important to give clear instructions for doing this such as protecting
habaki, tsuba, etc., from excessive force!)

When looking at a sword that's presented to you, it is always advisable -- 
for your own education -- to make a judgement about the blade before looking
at the nakago. That alone can save you some money by being dazzled by a "big
mei." All fun stuff!!

Ron
STL


----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, January 09, 2006 10:04 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...


Hi Patrik,
I am not nearly as knowledgeable in Nihonto as everyone
else on this messege board but I do have an extensive "sales" background. A
couple of things come to mind before you buy this piece.
If the Seller is knowledgeable in Nihonto, then he would be painfully aware
of how important it is to the Buyer to examine the nakago. As mentioned
earlier, this should be a simple process. Taking this one step farther, "if"
the seller is knowledgeable, mabe there is something on the nakago that
he/she doesn't want you to see. This would all be related to the asking
price of course. If the seller isn't knowledgeable, have you explained to
the seller just how simple it would be to remove the tsuka?
Just seems "odd" to me. Has anyone else out there been denied access to a
nakago? I'm curious.

Mark Jaillet

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mark - As Patrik wrote a few messages ago, he has purhased the sword and at the price, I would think he could not had gone wrong with it. Will be quite
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mark -

As Patrik wrote a few messages ago, he has purhased the sword and at the
price, I would think he could not had gone wrong with it. Will be quite
interesting to see if the blade has a mei or not! (Trying to get an atari
with my Bungo-to thought!)

>Has anyone else out there been denied access to a nakago? I'm curious.

In the past fast-approaching 40 years (now that sound scarey!!) I would
suspect I've been denied access to a nakago perhaps half-dozen times. If you
have the opportunity to have the sword in-hand, then at least you can make a
judgement from the blade's quality. If buying it from a photo, well, it is a
gamble and would certainly limit how much you would offer for it because of
that gamble. I've found that most "owners" will, if you explain it to them
in a knowledgeable and polite manner, will allow the tsuka to be removed. If
buying through the mail, once they learn about the possibility of a
signature, curiosity usually takes over and off comes the tsuka. (Always
important to give clear instructions for doing this such as protecting
habaki, tsuba, etc., from excessive force!)

When looking at a sword that's presented to you, it is always advisable --
for your own education -- to make a judgement about the blade before looking
at the nakago. That alone can save you some money by being dazzled by a "big
mei." All fun stuff!!

Ron
STL


----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, January 09, 2006 10:04 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...


Hi Patrik,
I am not nearly as knowledgeable in Nihonto as everyone
else on this messege board but I do have an extensive "sales" background. A
couple of things come to mind before you buy this piece.
If the Seller is knowledgeable in Nihonto, then he would be painfully aware
of how important it is to the Buyer to examine the nakago. As mentioned
earlier, this should be a simple process. Taking this one step farther, "if"
the seller is knowledgeable, mabe there is something on the nakago that
he/she doesn't want you to see. This would all be related to the asking
price of course. If the seller isn't knowledgeable, have you explained to
the seller just how simple it would be to remove the tsuka?
Just seems "odd" to me. Has anyone else out there been denied access to a
nakago? I'm curious.

Mark Jaillet

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...
messages.msgSnippet: If you find it says Made in China, that d probably make it worth a whole lot more. LOL I doubt any of the fakes have ever come out with that precise Mei. But
messages.messageBody:
If you find it says Made in China, that'd
probably make it worth a whole lot more. LOL I
doubt any of the fakes have ever come out with that precise Mei.

But hopefully, it'll be an authentic one.

Best Regards,

Andres

At 02:48 AM 1/9/2006, you wrote:
>Thanks for the answers
>
>I decied to bought this sword,maybe a stupid
>thing to do whitout seeing it "live" .But
>anyway, i liked the "look" of it.....(800$ including shipping)
>Talked to the owner,he had recived this sword as
>a gift from an older couple that had have this
>on the wall in their cabin, the man in that
>couple bought it in the 1920´s on a trip in a unknown country.
>He had helped them for some years whith the
>garden and so, and when they decied to sell the
>cabin they asked him if he wanted anything from
>the cabin,he just did think that the sword
>looked nice, (no intreset in japanese swords at
>all), so he took that and an old TV.
>He will not take the Tskua of it, he was scared that he gonna destroy it.
>Hopefully i gonna recive it under this week,
>gonna post some pics of the tang it when i have
>it in my hands. (and if it says "made in China", i let you know :-)
>
>Best Regards
>
>Patrik
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks for the answers I decied to bought this sword,maybe a stupid thing to do whitout seeing it live .But anyway, i liked the look of it.....(800$
messages.messageBody:
Thanks for the answers

I decied to bought this sword,maybe a stupid thing to do whitout seeing it "live" .But anyway, i liked the "look" of it.....(800$ including shipping)
Talked to the owner,he had recived this sword as a gift from an older couple that had have this on the wall in their cabin, the man in that couple bought it in the 1920´s on a trip in a unknown country.
He had helped them for some years whith the garden and so, and when they decied to sell the cabin they asked him if he wanted anything from the cabin,he just did think that the sword looked nice, (no intreset in japanese swords at all), so he took that and an old TV.
He will not take the Tskua of it, he was scared that he gonna destroy it.
Hopefully i gonna recive it under this week, gonna post some pics of the tang it when i have it in my hands. (and if it says "made in China", i let you know :-)

Best Regards

Patrik

From: Barry Thomas
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, January 09, 2006 7:14 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...


"Patrik Danielsson" wrote:


Hello to you all, i was offered this sword, would like some feedback about it
from you all,the seller dont want to take the tsuka off it, at this moment. Any
of you have any iedas about it???

http://photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/Japan/


Well, it looks basically "OK" to me even if the condition is a little off. It
all comes down to price...

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...
messages.msgSnippet: Hello Patrik - Actually, I like the looks of this sword even though the blade condition is out-of-polish. The mountings look interesting with Higo style fuchi
messages.messageBody:
Hello Patrik -

Actually, I like the looks of this sword even though the blade condition is out-of-polish. The mountings look interesting with Higo style fuchi and kashira, nice shakudo menuki that look possibly early, nice tsuba. The blade seems to have a nice shape and the kissaki being extended makes me think possibly sue-koto possibly. The hamon as was mentioned, seems a chu-suguha. I just wonder if this could be a sue-koto Bungo blade, a wild guess considering its condition but I'll say that anyway. Hope you end up with it.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: need some advices on a sword...
messages.msgSnippet: ... feedback about it from you all,the seller dont want to take the tsuka off it, at this moment. Any of you have any iedas about it??? ... Hello Mr
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Patrik Danielsson"
<patrik.danielsson@e...> wrote:
>
> Hello to you all, i was offered this sword, would like some
feedback about it from you all,the seller dont want to take the
tsuka off it, at this moment. Any of you have any iedas about it???
>
> http://photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/Japan/
>
>
> Best Regards
>
> Patrik
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
Hello Mr Danielsson, From the pics it looks like the sword in
general is genuine. All the essentials are there. The blade is so
out of polish it is hard to really comment on it. There seems to be
a large hamon based on suguha but the kissaki pics show zilch. It is
so easy to remove and replace the tsuka that I do not understand
this persons reticence. Maybe tight from rusting? So much can be
determined from the nakago that it is a pity we can not see it. John
